Request Foods
3460 John F. Donnelly Drive
Holland, MI  49424




Risk Management Program
Executive Summary


Request Foods' single facility is located in Holland, Michigan sitting on 20 acres of land in Holland Township.  Request Foods consistently employs 550 full time individuals on an annual basis in addition to utilizing a large temporary force during busier production seasons.  

Request Foods is a privately held, for profit, organization with the primary objective of producing high quality convenience frozen food entrees (mainly pasta and chicken based products) as well as side dishes for a large spectrum of nationally known companies.  The majority of its products are sold in both the retail and institutional market places.  Due to the frozen nature of the food products that are produced, Request Foods utilizes a series of coolers, spiral freezers and storage freezers to maintain the integrity of its products and raw materials.  The agent/chemical that is used at the facility to perform the cooling and freezing of the environment and products is Anhydrous Ammonia.  Anhydrous Ammonia is a substance regulated by the government.  The current maximum inventory of Anhydrous Ammonia at Request Foods is 140,000 pounds.  The majority of this inventory is considered "in process" cycling through the refrigeration equipment (compressors, evaporators, condensers, pumps, etc.).  There are 150 pieces of refrigeration equipment within the Ammonia system at Request Foods.  Presently, there are two large receivers located on the property, one on the southeast corner of the facility, and the second, on the east roof of the facility.  There are also, seven smaller receivers located within the facility in the engine rooms.

At Request Foods, management has taken every step necessary to provide a safe work environment for its team members and has been actively involved with the local Holland Township Fire Department and Ottawa County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) in k

eeping them, and the surrounding community, informed of the Ammonia supply at the facility.  Request Foods complies with all OSHA, MIOSHA, DEQ and EPA regulations that pertain to the frozen food industry, employee's safety and health, as well as the community's safety and health.  Chemical safety is just one of the elements of the Request Foods safety program that it takes very seriously and vows to implement any, and all, safety related procedures as a means to comply with regulations and to ensure the safety of its employees and surrounding environment.

Specifically, Request Foods complies with the OSHA PSM standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR 1910.119)) and utilizes the majority of the elements of the PSM program as the company's general accidental release prevention program detailing and outlining specific steps in the prevention of Ammonia spills.  As a result of Request Foods' compliance with the OSHA PSM standard, specifically the Process Hazards Analysis element of the program, Request Foods has been able to identify specific areas surrounding the Ammonia system that may require greater attention.  This has come in the form of requiring more stringent documentation of process equipment maintenance and preventative maintenance steps, bringing to the attention of contractors working on the system the required safety procedures, and emphasizing a greater breadth of awareness amongst the entire Request Foods employee population and training topics for the affected employees with their job responsibilities most closely associated with the Ammonia refrigeration system.



Should there be a release of Ammonia from the Request Foods facility, estimates have been made with the assistance of the Holland Township Planning Office regarding the amount of off-site impact (human) there may be immediately around the facility given specific distances for worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario.  Using the EPA's RM

P*Comp. worst-case scenario model, a scenario was hypothed to include a release of 27,000 pounds of liquid and vaporizing Ammonia at a spill rate of 2,700 pounds per minute (10 minute total release time) with wind speeds at 1.5 meters/second.  Given the models equations, an endpoint, or vulnerability zone was calculated to be 1.50 miles in all directions from the center of the facility.  Assuming this worst-case scenario should happen, the estimated residential population within distance to the 1.50-mile endpoint is 10,883 individuals.  There is a major commercial, office and industrial area surrounding the Request Foods facility, which would increase the amount of human impact if such a release were to occur.  Beyond the immediate industrial and commercial population, as well as the residential population, there are schools, adult foster care centers and other public receptors within the 1.50-mile endpoint that would have been affected.  For this scenario of release, there are also no National or state parks, forests or monuments, no designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves or refuges, nor any Federal wilderness areas.  Control measures are in place, however, to prevent this type, or amount, of catastrophic release from occurring.   Request Foods has written operating procedures that thoroughly examine the normal daily operations as well as emergency operations of the ammonia system, which include numerous safeguards for preventing large releases.  As well, high-level ammonia alarms are present in the system which would prevent ammonia receivers from every being over 60% full which would decrease the potential of their being 27,000 pounds of liquid ammonia in a receiver at any one time down to 16,200 pounds.    On the contrary, Request Foods does not have any passive mitigation methods (dikes, berms, drains, sumps, etc.) that would alleviate such a release.

Examining the alternative release scenario, again utilizing the EPA??A?s RMP*Comp??A? scenario this time a

ssuming a pipe leak of liquid ammonia, a quantity of 6,510 pounds of Ammonia could be estimated to be released to the atmosphere, either internal or external, at a release rate of 651.0 pounds/minute for 10 minutes.  Wind speed in this scenario is estimated to by 3.0 meters/second.  These variables present a 0.20-mile distance to the endpoint, or a 0.20 vulnerability zone surrounding the facility.  Assuming the alternative case spill scenario should happen, the estimated residential population within distance to the 0.20-mile endpoint is 3 individuals.  There is a major commercial, office and industrial area surrounding the Request Foods facility, which would increase the amount of human impact if such a release were to occur.  Beyond the immediate industrial and commercial population, as well as the limited residential population, there are no schools, hospitals, or recreation areas within the 0.20-mile endpoint that would have been affected.  For this scenario of release, there are also no National or state parks, forests or monuments, no designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves or refuges, nor any Federal wilderness areas.  Control measures are in place, however, to prevent this type, or amount, of alternative release from occurring.   Request Foods has written operating procedures that thoroughly examine the normal daily operations as well as emergency operations of the ammonia system, which include numerous safeguards for preventing large releases.  These include the exact locations of shut offs and isolation valves to prevent excessive amounts of ammonia from escaping into the atmosphere.   For an internal release, Request Foods does have the option of a sprinkling system and emergency shutdown systems as passive mitigation methods, yet does not posses any means for mitigation of external releases (dikes, berms, drains, sumps, etc.). 

The Request Foods emergency response program includes actions be taken by Request Foods personnel pertaining to internal and

external Ammonia releases as well as the contacting of external agencies in the event of an Ammonia release which may effect the surrounding environment or community.  In the event of a release to the outside atmosphere that may pose a hazard to the surrounding environment or community, a notification list has been outlined.  An Incident Commander has been identified at Request Foods who will direct on-site response actions until a more qualified, or authorized, individual should be present at the scene.   Local emergency responders such as the Ottawa County Sheriff Department and Holland Township Fire Departments are first on the list of responders.  




During an emergency response the Ottawa County Sheriff Department will provide site security at the street entrances.  The Request Foods HAZMAT team will have primary responsibility to manage and respond to the emergency.  Their duties are focused upon controlling the release, evacuation of personnel, and mitigation.  The Ottawa County HAZMAT team will provide qualified HAZMAT responders as backup to the plant HAZMAT team.  Their primary responsibilities include; providing emergency medical treatment, transportation and responder decontamination, as well as emergency back-up. The Holland Township Fire Department/Ottawa County HAZMAT performs these functions for the facility.   Public notification to the surrounding community would be the responsibility of the local authorities.  Request Foods personnel would initiate immediate notification to the adjacent industrial facilities.

Secondary calls will follow to the MDEQ, the National Response Center (if release was over 100 pounds), Ottawa County Local Emergency Planning Committee, Chemtrec, and the Holland Board of Public Works if the spill might affect the sewer systems, and MIOSHA if there were any injuries/fatalities as a result of the release.  

In the event of an internal Ammonia release that does not affect the outside atmosphere or surrounding environment,

procedures are in place to quickly notify one of the designated Emergency Coordinators at Request Foods.  Actions are then taken to promptly asses the extent of the release, measure the respective air contamination through testing with a portable gas monitoring device, in addition to decisions being made to evacuate the immediate affected work area(s).  The internal alerting system at Request Foods is primarily the use of 2-way radios by all maintenance and operations team members.

Training received and drills conducted at Request Foods pertaining specifically to the Anhydrous Ammonia system include:  Annual evacuation drills to ensure that Request members are aware of the procedures and individual responsibilities in evacuating the facility in a timely manner, Hazardous Materials handling and Personal Protective Equipment training for authorized team members with access to the refrigeration system, First Aid and CPR certification training for members identified as Emergency Responders as well as Hazard Communication training to all team members, affected and authorized, reinforcing their knowledge of the presence and dangers of hazardous chemicals on the Request Foods property.  The Request Foods HAZMAT team is trained by an outside agency on an annual basis, and reviews HAZMAT response procedures on a regular basis.

As a result of the implementation of the Process Safety Management program, a designated PSM Coordinator has been identified within the organization that has the responsibility to ensure the continual maintenance and procedural compliance with the elements of the program. With this oversight, the continued safe operation of the refrigeration system will continue at an even more heightened level.   It should also be noted that recently an outside alarm/security company has begin monitoring the Request Foods Ammonia alarms. Through the evaluation of the Process Hazardous Analysis element of the PSM program, a number of procedural changes, in addition
to administrative modifications, may happen resulting in a positive effect on the safety of the Ammonia refrigeration system at Request Foods.
